name: 4-chloro-3-fluorobenzyl bromide
Reason: To predict the melting point of 4-chloro-3-fluorobenzyl bromide, we consider the basic unit, benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. Each substituent on the benzene can affect the melting point. Halogens such as chlorine and bromine generally increase the melting point due to their high electronegativities and the larger size of bromine. The fluorine atom introduces a smaller inductive effect compared to chlorine or bromine because of its smaller size, but still increases the melting point because of its high electronegativity. The benzyl (CH2Br) group, which is larger compared to just a bromine atom, also contributes to an increase in the melting point due to the addition of more carbon atoms which increases the molecular weight and van der Waals forces. We might consider approximate increments as follows: for chlorine +10 degrees Celsius, for fluorine +5 degrees Celsius, and for the benzyl group (mainly due to the bromide) an addition of around +20 degrees Celsius.
